SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graham)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: William Henry Sherring Gauge

Present Address: Red Deer Hill

Pioneer Address: Red Deer Hill (1894)

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1894

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? -7-

How many of these were bachelor's homes? -1-

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Then was a lot more visiting done in the early days.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal given when people had come unexpectedly (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a month, etc.?

NO.
PIONEER ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days?

4. Were you often invited to a party? If so, what kind of parties were they?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "meets" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates, if possible, telling what the "meets" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Here these more frequent in later years? Give dates, yes, and no.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from 1 to 4, one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a month, etc.?

NO. Let us hear stories to small, & in much detail.

They can be found in our newspapers (especially a booklet) listing acts of kindness, going to another's house (especially a bachelor) taking care of the necessary food and other needs.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? -7-

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 1

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Monthly in the afternoon to get home in time to do the chores.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal? Would people have come unexpectedly (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) That term was used very frequently (People were quite friendly).

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Lots of them.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

All the buildings were built of logs, it took quite a few men to put a building up. Four men with axes cut down the trees, then they would help men to help lift the logs to their place. Sometimes, they would help men to dig a well. It took several men. Then there were few hired men in those days. The work was hard.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst farmers drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?

NO. Lots of us had homes too small to do much visiting. They used to put on surprise parties sometimes, a couple of couples would go to another home (especially a bachelor) taking all the necessary food with them. I was always made very welcome.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

8. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

10. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "meals" were for, and how often they occurred.

11. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, what kind?

12. Drives or dances in homes? Describe.

13. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

14. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from 1-4-8-3?

15. How long as you known to one another at definite times, — every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?

16. They used to send an expensive/valuable something, a copy of something going to another house (probably a birthday) taking out the necessary food with them. — or you always made very delicious...
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

It was used a lot at times - for box socials etc., we had a very jolly library club during the society. A patch of a big gate night, and a fairnight. It was always used for the School Christmas tree and concert.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

For a long time it was the only building we had for public meetings, political etc., although not very convenient. The school (in some years extended to the floor) was not complete for adults - we'd bring plates & pans across them.

9. When was your first community hall built? In 1916, we had a Community Hall, we built it in 1916.

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? We used stones from the river bed & other materials.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? We have no village hall or school hall, but a large hall in the town.

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)?

The Hall was used for meetings, dances, etc., we made a small charge to others than Great Green Members.

The Hall was built about 8 years ago. It was partly owned, nothing has been done about the insurance policy yet. The town can build a large hall closer to us here that now. This was a good idea.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as mentioned in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

They were bundled up in a blanket or bed, with plenty of blankets.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

Many were stabled, if at a farm, if at the hall, just blankets.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Pedro, Cribbage, Canasta, Whist, Poker, Pinochle, Bridge, etc.

Was there card playing for a prize?

Yes, a prize at third dance, Ladies' Night.

What dances were popular?

(Waltz, Polka, Square, etc.)

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Not much.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some were a little more strict than others.

But, on a rule, things went off fairly well.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

Not in a rural community like Red Deer Hill.

We are 15 miles from Prince Albert, our nearest town.

I had some visiting cards, handed to my wife when we were married.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Personally I did not believe in chivarees. But they do have them. I have seen some, whether in good spirits or both parties were good. I have known cases, after a wedding where the groom has gone out and thrown all kinds of rubbish; but of later years, this custom disappears.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

I don't see much difference. People knew each other well at home made chairs, benches, etc. If you wished to make presentations, they always helped you just the same. As a young schoolteacher of 20, when I arrived here, it appeared to me homely. They were very generous, made time in any form if you were always made very welcome.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

We organized a lodge of the I.O.O.F. about 1902, as a lodge of the Patrons of Industry.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

The farmers thought we should have some organization.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

I think about 1912. Mrs. Macdonald of Abernethy tried to get a branch here. We came out of a good meeting. We met all the farmers and joined up.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

About 85%.

How many women belonged? Quite a few. How often did it meet?

Monthly.

My wife was the first Women's director for the Prince Albert area.

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

We discussed farm problems, sent delegates to the Convention, joined in with other local, and raised funds for the car load.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Yes

When was it organized?

1912, a Homemakers club at Tea Park about 14 miles west.

Approximately how many women belonged to it? 12

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
22. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns such as gloved and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially.

23. Was the chivalrous known in your community? If so, how?

24. Describe any other details of chivalry, parties, etc., that you remember.

25. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

26. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

27. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

There was a W.C.T.U. about 1908, a library & debating club started about 1901. It only lasted a few years. There were five or six English families. They were a great help in organizing, but most of them moved to other places of things that sat died out.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

At the School House, chiefly.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No.

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Yes, dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides? The first cinematograph show was put on by two young men from Prince Albert about 1903.

What were the slides about? All I can remember was a film showing harvesting on the farm of Mr. H. H. the Governor of Manitoba. It caused quite a lot of excitement as they put the film in backwards so we saw the sheaves flying back into the barn.

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Knife, marble ball.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Play house, skipping rope, Ball, etc.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the names of such clubs when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who became members, where, young people, whether it included people only from the town or district (for example, within a school connected with the church), so they need not be included here.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Do.

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

21. What games did boys play in summer (jump rope, marbles, etc.)? Play house, skipping rope, ball, etc.

What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   Sliding, skating, snowshoeing

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   Checkers, dominoes, various card games

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   Some times we'd all join in... other times the children only.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   In the winter long evenings, quite a lot of time... but there was some chores for the children... heard the cows pasturing the fields, or some house work for those who went to school.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   About 1898.

26. Who organized it?  
   The families in the settlement, they would arrange for hot games, near the ground, erect a booth etc.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   People came from all around, neighboring Ball team was coming, lots of their friends came too.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   Ball games, this would generally be some races for the children, possibly some horse races for the men.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   They would spread sheets, a tall cloth on the ground for enough for all to sit down, the food brought by every family coming, was placed indiscriminately on the cloth. The people sat all around on everything you could think of, cold meats, picnic chicken, sandwiches, salads, cakes, pies, ad lib.

Sea was the usual drink. Some of the men poured it out.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   The ground.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   Most came in time for dinner, usually had to quit soon after supper, go home & do the chores. Sometimes ending up with a dance at one of the houses.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Family," "Mushroom," or others; checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

Some time was spent at the house. The children often went out to play.

Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

23. Did children ever go out to play? 

Did they ever go out alone? 

Did they ever go out with friends?

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

Picnics and Sports

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 

Give year and month if possible. 

26. Who organized it? 

The families or the settlement, the school, the church, the town council, the mayor, etc.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, zone organization, etc.? 

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnics you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? 

Picnics were usually held at the homes of the host family or at the school grounds.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? 

They would spread sheets, a table cloth on the ground for everyone to sit on, and eat together.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 

There were usually pies, cake, and punch.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 

Mid-day or late afternoon. Sometimes ending up with a dance at nine o'clock.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

I thought the people were so wonderfully sociable, very little side of all out for an enjoyable time.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

All the picnics started in the early days were held in a fan park, but later on they were started raising money achieved their end. But the town was found to be socially friendly.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Basketball, Cricket, Skating, Bowling (for your data we agency)

A club of eight years had a successful club.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Basketball

What year? 1944

How long did it continue? For a few years

When other clubs started up.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Around about 1898, the first Englishmen organized a cricket club. We had some good games. The Republic of India, which came out and played with us, we went back to Canada. The game used to give quite a lot of amusement to the local, they called it "Cricket Day."

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Now in the settlement, in 1895 we kept a lake open all winter, using a skid team and a scraper. We all turned out for evening. Built a fire at the edge of the lake, always swept the rink clean after we finished skating. Most of the farmers own daughters in the settlement turned out and had a glorious time.

(Signed only 22 Nov.)
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe the large community picnic which you knew of in the early days, picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

38. Name any other sport teams that were organized before 1911, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what was it used for?

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

How or by whom was it constructed?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

I am afraid not.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

Not very many. I bought out Shakespeare, Jonson, Coleridge, Milton, Whittier. Both were chiefly tragedies and a boy at school.

I also had Dickens' Pickwick papers, David Copperfield, Tom Brown's Schooldays.

I also had poems by Edna Lyall, Bertha, Donovan. We had "In the Golden Days," "Knight Errant." (All of these I still have, about 300 now.)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

They exchanged, very readily, with what books they had.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

Personally, I bought a few many. I am very fond of books, Jean Compton, her friend, Dora, Ralph Connon, S.P. Rowe, etc.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

My friends sent me quite a lot from England. Van Mearns' Books, the Sherlock Holmes, J.M. Barrie, etc.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

Yes, a library from the University for a few years. I think around about 1910—a thousand.

48. Was there a school library? Yes. When was it begun? Early in the 1900s.

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

He had (the librarian) a fund of $100 a year in library books. He got the full grant. Some of the books were used by parents of adults.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?

I cannot say.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the
   names and authors of all books, if any, which you brought, and what kind.)
   (Use extra sheets if necessary)

old very many

43. How many of your neighbors bought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

My exchanges were very rarely with adult books. My trade was not heavy.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

Personally I had a good many. If anyone had any I would be glad to lend them.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

my friends and family often sent me books.

47. Have you ever had any "traveling library" books in your community or school?

Yes a library from the library by mail service of their trend about 1910 - a thousand.

48. Was there a school library?

Then was it begun early in 1910.

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to
read at home? (The teacher) I suppose at least $10 a year / In early
periods I felt the best period. - Some of the better ones used by parents

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading
    material?

It cannot pay.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? 
   When was it started? 
   Who started it? 
   Is it still in existence? 
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   A Prairie Allotment weekly. The Advocate. I believe it was called.
   The Family Herald was a great favorite.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.
   We soon changed the Family Herald; we had the National Farmer. Farmers' Weekly.
   I took a Calgary paper. I forget its name. (Perhaps the Ripper?). etc.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.
   I knew a lady (Mrs. Heritage) obtained them; they circulated through a few homes.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   Most of the ones I described in #2

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
   Not very much. The Family Herald helped out quite a lot.
   It also came from me and my public speaking in Agriculture, men from the Experimental farm at Saddle, Ranch.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so, when was it started? Who started it? How many people used it? To what extent did it exist? What arrangements were made for borrowing books?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? The Family Herald was a great favorite.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain ones and started others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?
   None.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?
   One had a piano organ when I came out.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.
   New piano, we have organ at the school & church.
   Several people have pianos in their homes now.
   They were rare in the 90's.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.
   Singing was always popular and much enjoyed.
   There was no uncommon thing to dance to a mouth organ or fiddle. Was available in the community? (Were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?
   "Jingle Bells," "After the Ball was Over," "Tommy Atkins," "I'm Wild for Love," "Wipe Me Up in My Old Stable," etc.

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.
   Not then. It is more popular now with a larger population of Southern European.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.
   I can remember one old man, Willie Smith, who called me at any public meeting, loud singing, "Between the Falls and Cavern," an old song number of very good connection.

63. Was there a band in your community? No When was it started? How long did it continue?

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

I might describe one experience. I was on a trip on my way home. One day I had my crop cut without warning when a herd of pigs came in & trashed my crops down. I knew where they came from. The man had (cause of pigs) I went & saw him & he said he'd send his boys down & drive them home. They couldn't do it. I made a small corral in the field & with the aid of a fellow & my neighbors we captured about 30 & told the owner. I'd sell them to collect damages. We had no fence in those days. He went to law & beat me. I had not a legal fence that fall. I made a legal plot a third acre the following summer. They came down on face before the plow was cut, many followed them. I went to the man again & took the minute with me. I told him about it. He said it was okay. He said he would drive them out & if they couldn't, we'd shoot them out. We did kill my sheep & cows also suffer the herd. I killed over 200 pigs.
